### **Accessibility & Inclusive Design**

**Alt text:**  
Provide simple, descriptive alt text for any visuals (e.g., *“Trainer speaking with participant in calm tone during crisis‑response workshop”*). Avoid decorative text in images when possible.

**Color contrast:**  
Use high‑contrast combinations (minimum 4.5:1) between text and background. Avoid conveying meaning by color alone—pair colors with icons or labels.

**Typography:**  
Choose legible sans‑serif fonts; maintain 12‑pt or larger body type. Ensure enough line spacing (1.4–1.6 × font size) for readability.

**Plain language:**  
Keep sentences short. Replace jargon with everyday wording (e.g., “getting professional help” instead of “accessing behavioral‑health interventions”).  

**Digital formats:**  
Make PDFs and slides screen‑reader friendly by tagging headings, reading order, and hyperlinks. Include the same resource links (988 / **findahelpline.com**) as live text.

**Inclusive tone:**  
Use person‑first or identity‑affirming language, respect pronouns, and avoid assumptions about background, culture, or experience.

---
